title: The late Mr

author.literal: CHAP. II.

title: Spectroscope as applied to the Sun
To find when Easter falls in 1880
Apian, who studied comets with great diligence. JMLunster writes on clocks and dials
Rheinhold (a friend of Copernicus), who constructed the Prutenic Tables-1555
Dee publishes a book on geometry
Recorde, said to have been the first modern English writer on astronomy and the sphere
Leonard Digges, author of The Prognostication Everlasting, and other works
Apparition of a new star in Cassiopeia, whose position is determined by HageciuS) by measuring the meridian altitude, and noting the time at which the observation was made
Gregory invents the reflecting telescope which now bears his name
Hooke detects the rotation of Jupiter on its axis
Cassini observes the transit of the shadow of a Jovian satellite
Homer propounds his discovery relating to the transmission of light, as detected 476 The History of Astronomy
Cassini discovers those satellites of Saturn now known as Tethys and Dione
La Hire's researches on the theory of refraction. 1 704. Rb'mer commences star observations with a meridian circle
Halley predicts the return in 1759 of the comet of 1682

note: th satellite of Saturn.
title: Foundation of the Royal Observatory
Cassini discovers the inclination of the 5 1715

note: P. Maraldi complete, at Dunkirk, the arc commenced by J. D. Cassini, 1719. Maraldi's researches on the rotation of Jupiter.
title: Bradley publishes his Tables of Jupiter's Satellites
Halley communicates to the Royal Society Newton's table of refractions

container-title: Foundation of the St. Petersburg Observatory. Harrison announces the gridiron compensation pendulum
title: Publication of Flamsteed's Historia, Celestis
Bianchini determines the rotation of Venus. Graham invents the mercurial pendulum
Bradley discovers the aberration of light
Destruction, by fire, of Copenhagen Observatory, in which were stored the observations of Rb'mer, and of Horrebow his successor, all of which are lost
Bouguer investigates the theory of refraction
Maraldi improves the theory of Jupiter's satellites. Maupertuis introduces into France Newton's theory
Le Monnier, and others measure an arc in Lapland, and Bouger and La Condamine one in Peru

note: D. Cassini. Clairaut im-
title: La Caille and Cassini (III) re-measure the arc of J
Bradley discovers the nutation of the Earth's axis. Bird commences his improvements in the graduation of instruments
Publication of Euler's Solar and Lunar Tables, and Wargentin's Tables of Jupiter's Satellites
Researches of Euler, Clairaut, and D'Alembert, on the theory of the planets. Mayer confirms by observation Cassini's theory of the lunar libration

note: Publication of Euler's Essay on the Motions of Jupiter and Saturn.
title: Bouguer, unacquainted with Savary's discovery, proposes a double object-glass micrometer, which he calls a heliometer
Publication of La Caille's Astronomic? Fundamenta

container-title: Researches by Clairaut and Lalande on the orbit of Halley's comet
title: Publication of La Caille's Solar Tables. Re-invention by Dollond of the achromatic object-glass
Publication of Halley's Planetary Tables by Lalande. Publication of an improved edition of Wargentin's Tables of Jupiter's Satellites
Publication of Mayer's Solar and Lunar Tables
Further researches by Bailly on Jupiter's satellites
Publication by Bode of Titius's law of planetary distances
Researches by La Grange on the attraction of spheroids; and by Laplace on the secular inequalities of the solar system
Experiments by Maskelyne on the Earth's attraction, on Mount Schehallien

note: Conn, des Temps, 1784.) Wargentin discovers that the inclination of Jupiter's 4th satellite is variable.
title: Herschel discovers the planet Uranus. Publication of Messier 's Catalogue of Nebulae
Publication of La Grange's Mecanique Analytique. Herschel suspects that the motions of the satellites of Uranus are retrograde

publisher: Publication of Delambre's Tables of Jupiter and Saturn
title: Herschel determines the rotation of Saturn, and discovers the satellites Mimas and Enceladus

note: BrinJcley appointed Director of the Dublin Observatory.
publisher: Publication of Delambre's Tables of Uranus
title: Herschel determines the rotation of Saturn's ring, and announces 2 new satellites of Uranus, which announcement has never been confirmed

container-title: Madras Observatory founded by H. E. I. C
title: Commencement of the Trigonometrical Survey of France. Publication of Taylor's Logarithms, Lalande's improved Planetary Tables, and De ZacJis first Solar Tables
Laplace's researches on the satellites of Jupiter and the figure of the Earth. Schro'ter determines the rotation of Venus

container-title: Ivory's Theorems on the Figure of the Earth
title: Troughtori's improvements in the graduation of instruments
Groombridge's Refraction Tables. Carlini's Solar Tables. Lindenau's Tables of Venus. Bessel appointed director of the Observatory of Konigsberg
Erection of Troughton's Mural Circle at Greenwich

container-title: Commencement of the Zeitschrift filr Astronomic
note: which goes on till 1818.
title: Foundation of the Konigsberg Observatory

container-title: Poisson'S researches on Planetary Perturbations. 1817. Delambre's Tables of Jupiter's Satellites. Damoitfeau's researches on Halley's comet
title: 8 I'D". Lindenau assigns a new value to the constant of nutation

note: De Zach starts the Correspondance Astronomique, which goes on till 1825.
title: Publication of Bessel's Fundamenta Astronomiee

publisher: Publication of Brinkley's Tables of Refraction
title: Foundation of the Royal Astronomical Society of London. ReichenbacK's meridian circle erected at Konigsberg
Commencement of the Berlin Zones. Jones's mural circle erected at Greenwich
Researches of Bessel on the oscillation of the pendulum
The Royal Astronomical Society commences the publication of the Monthly Notices
Airy discovers a long inequality in the motions of Venus and the Earth
Herschel's researches on the satellites of Uranus. Lubboclcs theory of the Moon

container-title: Researches of Hansen on the Lunar Theory
title: Erection of Repsold's meridian circle at Kb'nigsberg
Peters determines the constant of nutation ; Baily determines the mean density of the Earth by a repetition of the Cavendish experiment

Airy's measurement of the arc of parallel comprised between Valencia and Greenwich. Discovery of the planet Neptune. Publication of the results of the observations of the planets made at Greenwich between 1750 and

publisher: The Royal Astronomical Society of London moves from Somerset House to Burlington House
title: Coggia's comet. Transit of Venus on December 8, for which enormous preparations were made all over the world. Completion of Le Verrier's Planetary researches by the publication of the theories of Uranus (revised) and Neptune. Publication of Cornu's investigations respecting the velocity of light
Unprecedented absence of spots on the Sun
Discovery of the 2 satellites of Mars by A
Publication by the Russian Government of Schmidt's great Map of the Moon
No fewer than 20 minor planets discovered, the largest number ever found in any one year
Two bright comets visible to the naked eye in July

container-title: A Conference at "Washington adopts Greenwich as the Prime Meridian
title: 6. Large comet visible in September-1884
Temporary star visible in the great nebula in Andromeda

Completion of the great 36-inch Refractor of the Lick Observatory. An International Conference at Paris agrees on a scheme to photograph the whole Heavens. 1 888. Publication of the result of Pickering's photometric researches into the brilliancy of 4143 stars
Important total eclipse of the Sun on Jan. I, well observed in many parts of North America
Contains 1025 stars (excluding duplicates), observed at Rhodes, incorporated by Ptolemy into his Mcyd\T) 'Svvragis, or The Almagest, and by him reduced to the epoch of 137 A.D
